Award.AwardTitle: California State University, East Bay (CSUEB) Noyce Scholars Program Phase II

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The California State University, East Bay (CSUEB) Noyce Scholars Program Phase II (NSP II) is building on and expanding Phase I efforts to recruit and support academically successful senior mathematics and science majors and STEM professionals in completing a credential program and becoming highly effective teachers in high needs, urban schools. This four-year joint project, in collaboration with K-12 districts across Alameda and Contra Costa counties, supports 32 new math and science teachers (16 scholarships in year 2 and 16 in year 3) and focuses on two areas: 1) continuing to increase the number of middle and high school math and science teachers obtaining their credentials at CSUEB and 2) informing understanding of how best to attract, prepare, and provide ongoing support in order to retain highly effective STEM teachers by expanded evaluation of program efforts and the effectiveness of participating scholars. The NSP II is significant in its focus on the early recruitment of teacher candidates who are highly qualified in disciplinary areas.

The East Bay Area, which includes Alameda and Contra Costa Counties, supports an ethnically and racially diverse population. STEM professionals are in high demand but there are significant shortages in the workforce of those possessing competence in science and math. The future economic health of the region depends increasingly on an educational system capable of preparing teachers to respond successfully to the needs of students who require intensive and effective educational programs in science and math. The Noyce scholars furnish the tools to their students that enable underrepresented groups to be competitive in the workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Results from Prior NSF Support

 

CSUEB Noyce Scholars Program, Phase II - Award #1340097 –

Grant Period – September, 2012 - August, 2018

Results - Intellectual Merit:  The CSUEB Noyce Scholars Phase II program has supported 34 math and science majors to earn their teaching credential and to begin teaching in high needs schools. Of the 38 original scholarships awarded, 32 recipients have earned their credential, 2 are still working on coursework to complete their credential, 1 left the program for documented medical reasons and 3 left the program without earning their credential. Of the 32 who have earned their credential, 9 have completed their teaching obligation (out of 13 who could have completed their commitment by now) and 6 have taught in high needs schools beyond their Noyce commitment. Some of the scholars chose to work part-time due to family commitments and others chose to start their career in a school that is not in a high needs district. All of these scholars plan to meet their teaching commitment. Each scholar will teach at least 150 students per year and so far have served over 5550 students. With continued commitments and Cohort IV beginning their teaching this year in 2018, the project expects to impact over 8700 students. The evaluation research has informed the program’s practice and has been disseminated through presentations and websites.

Results - Broader Impacts:  The East Bay Area of San Francisco, which includes Alameda and Contra Costa Counties, consists of an extremely ethnically diverse population. STEM professionals are in high demand, but there are significant long-term shortages in the workforce of those possessing competence in science and mathematics. The future economic health of the region depends increasingly on an educational system capable of preparing science and math teachers to respond successfully to the demand for STEM teachers and the needs of students who require intensive and effective educational programs in science and mathematics. The Noyce scholars have become highly effective teachers within their schools and districts and furnish the tools that enable underrepresented groups to be competitive within the increasingly mathematical, scientific and technical workforce. These scholars annually serve over 100 students each year.

Publications:  An article, "Successful Methods at Addressing the Teacher Shortage" is in submission at Issues in Teacher Education. The foundations for this article is a report published by Gibson and Associates (G&A) (See: Supporting STEM education through the Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at CSUEB, Djordjevich, N., Issus, Apr 8, 2018.). This report was widely distributed via social media outlets by Gibson and Associates, a well-established consultancy that has presented at the California Department of Education, local foundations, and city governments. Through shares of links, these finding were seen by over 200 policymakers, university, and local education agency officials, and program managers seeking to solve their immediate and practical challenges of STEM teacher recruitment and retention. Evidence of Research Products and Their Availability:  Evaluation tools and instruments were developed and are available on the mathematics department website at CSUEB. These instruments included questionnaires and protocols that ascertain how Scholars became aware of the program, what motivated them to enroll in the program, their STEM content knowledge and experience prior to the program, and their teaching experience. Other tools looked at the perception of the Impact of the program after one year of being in the program. Other tools include in-service questionnaires for Noyce Scholars to reflect back on their credentialing experience to identify the experiences that best prepared them and how this can be improved in the future. Our survey of students of Noyce Scholars asked both subject affinity questions and about observed teaching practices of their teachers.
